title: 109_hr4622
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teachers for Tomorrow's Careers Act of 2005" and pertains to qualified tuition and related expenses. The Act "Teachers for Tomorrow's Careers Act of 2005" extends the termination date to December 31, 2006, and adjusts the applicable dollar limit for taxable year 2006. The Act "Teachers for Tomorrow's Careers Act of 2005" extends the termination date to December 31, 2006, and adjusts the applicable dollar limit for taxable year 2006. In the case of qualified science, technology, engineering, or math teachers and professionals, specific payment thresholds are outlined based on adjusted gross income. The Act "Teachers for Tomorrow's Careers Act of 2005" extends the termination date to December 31, 2006, and adjusts the applicable dollar limit for taxable year 2006. For qualified science, technology, engineering, or math teachers and professionals, payment thresholds are outlined based on adjusted gross income. In the case of such teachers or professionals, subsection (b) does not apply, and certification expenses include fees for initial certification as a teacher in the individual's State. The Act "Teachers for Tomorrow's Careers Act of 2005" extends the termination date to December 31, 2006, and adjusts the applicable dollar limit for taxable year 2006. For qualified science, technology, engineering, or math teachers and professionals, certification expenses include fees for initial certification in the individual's State licensing system. The deduction for such expenses is allowed in the taxable year when the individual meets the requirements. In a taxable year, a 'qualified science, technology, engineering, or math teacher' is an individual with a degree in a related field, at least 3 years of non-teaching professional experience in the field, and teacher certification. In a taxable year, a 'qualified science, technology, engineering, or math teacher' is an individual certified as a teacher in their State for the first time and employed part-time in an elementary or secondary school. A 'qualified science, technology, engineering, or math professional' is someone with a bachelor's or advanced degree in a related field, who has worked in a non-teaching role for at least 3 years in the past 10 years, and has incurred fees related to their profession in the current taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to payments made in taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act regarding the enrollment or attendance of an individual in courses required for initial certification as a teacher of science, technology, engineering, or math in their State licensing system.
